D:Sections of the bladder show an invasive transitional cell carcinoma broadly
extending through the muscularis propria and into the perivesical fat (Dl-4). The
corresponding ,subjacent inked radial margin is negative for tumor. No definite
lymphovascular space invasion is identified .The adjacent urothelium along the
left lateral wall shows mild to moderate urothelial dysplasia. No carcinoma in

Sections of the prostate show a unilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma ,comprisedof variably sized glands infiltrating the fibromuecular stroma .The tumor ispredominantly along the left distal prostate (D19-20).No invasion into the
capsule or periprostatic soft tissue is identified .A few areas of atypical glandsare also seen in the right prostatic lobe (D15, D18 ).Two K903 stains performed

show intermittent staining of basal cells around critical glands ,supportingdiagnoses of high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and atypical basal cellhyperplasia .The apical urethral and radial margins as well as bilateral seminal
vesicles and vasa deferentia are all free of tumor.

reviewer :.sitla1"," Site: The primary tumor sites are the bladder and the prostate. Justification: The pathology report includes sections from the bladder and the prostate with diagnoses of cancer in both organs.

Laterality: The bladder cancer is not specified as to laterality, while the prostatic adenocarcinoma is predominantly on the left distal prostate. Justification: The report mentions that the bladder cancer is broadly extending through the muscularis propria and into the perivesical fat but does not specify if it is on one side or the other. Meanwhile, the prostatic adenocarcinoma is described as predominantly on the left distal prostate.

Histology: The bladder cancer is a transitional cell carcinoma, while the prostate cancer is an adenocarcinoma. Justification: The report describes the bladder cancer as an invasive transitional cell carcinoma and the prostate cancer as unilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma.
Stage: The staging information for both cancers is not provided in this report. Justification: The report does not include any mention of the staging for either the bladder or the prostate cancer.

Grade: The grade for the bladder cancer is not provided, while the prostatic adenocarcinoma is high-grade. Justification: The report does not include any mention of the grade for the bladder cancer, but it does describe the prostatic adenocarcinoma as unilateral and predominantly on the left distal prostate with a few areas of atypical glands in the right prostatic lobe. Two K903 stains performed show intermittent staining of basal cells around critical glands, supporting diagnoses of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and atypical basal cell hyperplasia.
Behavior: The behavior for both cancers is not provided in this report. Justification: The report does not include any mention of the behavior for either the bladder or the prostate cancer."

with squamoid features. 2.Tumor grade: Grade 3/3 (2003 WHO

abnormalities in bladder: Polypoid cystitis and nonspecific granulomatous
inflammation (post transurethral resection of bladder tumor) see note below.
7.Extension of tumor into organs adjacent to bladder: Prostate. 8.
Surgical margins: Urethral margin: Negative. Right ureter margin: High grade
urothelial dysplasia. Left ureter margin: Negative. Perivesical margin:

column2: the largest metastatic deposit measures 2.0 cm in greatest dimension

column1: The bladder mucosa, submucosa and muscularis propria of the dome and trigone
show an intense nonspecific granulomatous inflammatory reaction with foreign
body giant cells and focal necrotizing palisading granulomas (C8). These
findings are consistent with the patient's recent history of transurethral
resection of his bladder tumor, at these sites. The bladder mucosa is
otherwise benign with polypoid type chronic inflammation and focal hyperplasia,
with no residual carcinoma or dysplasia. There is a microscopic focus of high
grade urothelial carcinoma located in the outer half of the muscularis propria
of the trigone. A 0.3 cm focus of high grade urothelial carcinoma is present

column1: The prostatic urethral margin is shaved and submitted en face . The bladder is opened along the anterior midline to reveal a
tan-yellow friable papillary centrally necrotic tumor involving predominately the left posterior and left lateral wall extending down the
trigone measuring 6.1 x 4. 5 x 1.8 cm. The friable tissue -paftially occludes the left ureteral orifice and grossly approaches the
right ureteral orifice . The tumor extends into the prostatic parenchyma and lies 3.6 cm from the prostatic urethral margin. The
tumor is sectioned to reveal gross extension through the bladder wall into the perivesical fat. A full face section is taken ,bisected,
and submitted accordingly. The tumor also approaches the anterior soft tissue margin, and grossly invades the seminal vesicles
bilaterally . There is an additional ulcerated lesion in the dome of bladder that measures 2.2 x 1 .8cm and lies 1.8 cm from the
trigone , 2.5 cm from the right ureteral orifice, and 3.2 cm from the left ureteral orifice. The remaining bladder mucosa is dusky and
congested . TPS from both ulcerated tumor foci are submitted .Representative sections are submitted for routine processing.

UD - ulcerated defect within the dome

6. ""Behavior"": Malignant. Justification: This is a carcinoma, which is a malignant tumor by definition."

Invasive bladder cancer. Extensive desmoplastic reaction ?tumour.
Cystoprostatectomy weighing 375 g. The prostate measures 25x43x32 mm. The
bladder measures 55x70x65 mm. There is a ulcerated tumour at the posterior
bladder wall. It measures 50 mm x 30 mm with a thickness of 23 mm with invasion
of the bladder wall, but not obviously beyond into perivesical tissue. The
tumour is close to the seminal vesicles and the posterior resection margin.
The bladder contains an ulcerated poorly-differentiated micropapillary
transitional cell carcinoma with lymphovascular and perineural invasion. The
surface shows multinucleated giant cells amidst the granulation tissue. The
tumour is confined to the posterior bladder wall. The tumour infiltrates beyond
the muscularis propria of the posterior bladder wall with microscopic invasion
of vesical fat and is 2 mm away from the deep posterior margin. The tumour has
an accompanying fibrous response and abuts but does not invade the seminal
vesicles or prostate. Two separate deposits of tumour are seen distant from the
main mass, near the anterior wall.
The flat urothelium is not dysplastic.
See also for further information: both of the ureteric resections
The prostate shows hyperplasia and no evidence of prostatic adenocarcinoma nor
The features are those of a grade 3 transitional cell carcinoma of
Reviewer Initials Catr. Re.iev:ed"," 1. ""Site"": Bladder. Justification: The report clearly states that the specimen is a cystoprostatectomy and the tumor is located in the bladder.
2. ""Laterality"": Not provided. Justification: The report does not mention any laterality as the tumor is in the bladder which is a midline structure.
3. ""Histology"": Poorly-differentiated micropapillary transitional cell carcinoma. Justification: The microscopy section of the report mentions this specific type of carcinoma.

4. ""Stage"": pT3a Nx Mx. Justification: The summary section of the report states this stage, indicating the tumor has invaded beyond the muscularis propria but there is no information about lymph node or distant metastasis.
5. ""Grade"": III. Justification: The report mentions the tumor is a grade 3 transitional cell carcinoma.
6. ""Behavior"": Malignant. Justification: This is evident from the invasive nature of the tumor into the bladder wall and beyond, as well as lymphovascular and perineural invasion."

appearing mucosa .The remaining mucosa of the urinary bladder is unremarkable.
Bilateral ureterovesical junctions are identified and are uninvolved by tumor. The
attached right ureter measures 7 cm in length x 0.5 cm in diameter and the left
ureter measures 6 cm in length x 0.5 cm in diameter. Both are unremarkable. The
uterus measures 10 x 5 x 2.7 cm and is covered by unremarkable serosa.The cervix
measures 2.5 cm in length x 3 cm in diameter. The exocervix is covered by smooth
and glistening mucosa. The right ovary measures 3.5 x 1.5 x 0.7 cm. The right
fallopian tube measures 7 cm in length x 0.5 cm in diameter. Both appear normal.
The left ovary measures 4 x 1.5 x 0.8 cm. The left fallopian tube measures 9 cm in
length x 0.5 cm in diameter. A paratubal cyst is identified on the left fallopian
tube measuring 1.5 x 0.5 x 0.5 cm. The cervix and uterus are bivalved to reveal a
sessile polypoid lesion on the posterior endometrial wall measuring 1.2 x 1 x 0.4 Page 4 of 8

D:Sections of the bladder show invasive poorly differentiated urothelial
carcinoma of the right lateral wall (ulcerated lesion D2 -5)and dome (papillary
lesion (D7-l0)associated with both flat and papillary processes .The tumor
involves the lamina propria of the right lateral wall and the superficial
muscularis propria (D10) of the dome. Individual cells range from moderate to
markedly pleomorphic corresponding with grades 3 and 4/4. Urothelial carcinoma in
situ is seen in sections from the right lateral wall (D3-5) in association with the
invasive carcinoma .Sections of the non-neoplastic bladder mucosa show multifocal
chronic in flammation with associated reactive urothelial changes .Resection
margins are free of urothelial dysplasia and malignancy.

The pathology report lists the tumor as originating from the urinary bladder, while the intraoperative consultation reports it as arising from the right ureter. However, the final microscopic diagnosis confirms that the tumor is located in the urinary bladder.
Laterality: Not provided in the intraoperative consultation.
Histology: Invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma.
Stage: The stage is not provided in the report.
Grade: Individual cells range from moderate to markedly pleomorphic, corresponding with grades 3 and 4/4.

The bladder tumor has a very unusual morphology in that it shows dense solid
growth of predominantly epithelioid cells with focal spindling and few loose
myxoid areas. The epithelioid tumor cells are high grade, have modest
amphophilic cytoplasm and with brisk mitotic activity. In addition, numerous
osteoclast-like giant cells are distributed all throughout the tumor. Foci of
Immunohistochemical stains performed show that the tumor cells are nuclear
positive for GATA3 and with rare nuclear positivity for p63. Keratin Cam5.2, CK7
and CK20 are negative. The positivity for GATA3 and p63 are supportive for
Rare occurrence of osteoclast-like giant cells rich carcinoma, similar to the
current case, has been reported in the urinary tract. The few cases previously
reported showed an aggressive biologic behavior, see reference.
On part C, the right lymphadenectomy specimen shows large soft tissue deposits of carcinoma, which may represent overgrowths from a lymph nodal tumor
metastasis. No normal lymph node tissue however is identified. Of note, right
pelvic lymphadenectomy was performed previously (together with ureterectomy,
which was negative for tumor. Nodal status for the current bladder tumor

A. The first container is additionally identified as, ""Left pelvic lymph node"".
Received in formalin is an aggregate of yellow-tan ,soft, and lobulated tissue
fragments ranging in size from 1.1-1.4 cm in greatest dimension. The specimen is
dissected to reveal 10 lymph node candidates ranging in size from 0 .3-1.3 cm in
greatest dimension .The specimen is submitted as follows:
B. The second container is additionally identified as, ""bladder, prostate, left
and right vas deferens"". Received fresh and placed in formalin is a 250 g, 12.5
x 7 x 6 cm cystoprostatectomy specimen consisting of a 8.5 x 6.5 x 3 cm bladder
with attached mesenteric fat and a detached 3.2 x 2 x 1.7 cm probable tumor (or prostate). The right seminal vesicles and right vas deferens are not clearly
identified and a structure resembling the right seminal vesicles measure 1.5 x
1.5 x 0.4 cm and there is no identifiable right vas deferens structure. The
left vas deferens is not clearly identified and the left seminal vesicles
measures 2.5x 1.5 x 0.4 cm and a structure resembling the left vas deferens
measures 3 x 0.4 cm. The right ureteral stump measures 0.6 x 0.4 cm end
demonstrates an intact, patent lumen. The left ureteral stump is absent and the
left ureteral resection margin is taken where the ureter enters the bladder and
The right half of prostate and bladder is inked blue and the left half is inked
black. The bladder and prostate are opened anteriorly along the urethra. The
fragments of the outer surface of the tumor fragment are white-brown and shaggy.
Sectioning demonstrates a diffuse, homogenous, ill-defined, firm, white-tan.
The opened bladder reveals a 1.8 x 1.2 x 0.3 cm raised, soft, red-pink lesion on
the anterior wall designated as lesion #1, a 4 x 1.8 x 0.3 cm raised, soft,
red-pink lesion on the inferior posterior wall and right inferior lateral wall

mucosa and is 1.0 cm from the deep margin.

layer of the left lateral anterior wall and extending into the perivesicular
The surrounding bladder mucosa is edematous, wrinkled, congested, pink-tan with
a uniform 0.1-0.2 cm wall thickness. Bilateral ureteral orifices, adjacent to
the trigone, are identified and probe patent.

is probe patent to the trigone.

demonstrates rubbery, pink-tan, peri-urethral nodularity with no discrete
The opened bladder reveals a 5 x 4 cm ulcerated area located in the right

extends through the muscularis propria into the perivesical fat with a maximum

mucosa is edematous and pink-tan with a uniform 1.0 cm wall thickness. Gross

D:Sections of the bladder taken from the right.lateral wall show a poorly
differentiated invasive urothelial carcinoma (D1,6-9) extending through the entire
bladder wall into perivesical fat (D6,8,9). The tumor involves the right
ureterovesical junction (Dl) where it extends into the intramural portion of the
right ureter and extends through the wall into periureteral and perivesical fat.
The invasive tumor has an adjacent focus of urothelial carcinoma in situ (flat
lesion) (D9). While no lymphatic space invasion is seen, there is a focus of
vascular invasion noted (D8). The peripheral inked perivesical margin is free of
malignancy. Additional random sections of the bladder including the trigone and
bladder neck show foci of squamous metaplasia but no urothelial dysplasia or
urothelial carcinoma in situ. All final resection margins are free of both
Justification: The pathology report describes a poorly differentiated invasive urothelial carcinoma involving the bladder wall, right ureterovesical junction, and extending into perivesical fat.
Justification: The tumor primarily involves the right lateral wall of the bladder, right ureterovesical junction, and right proximal ureter.
Justification: The pathology report describes a poorly differentiated invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and distal ureters.
Stage: At least pT3a (using AJCC 8th edition)

Justification: The tumor invades through the bladder wall into perivesical fat, which is classified as pT3a. Since there is also extension into the intramural portion of the ureter and periureteral fat, it may be higher than pT3a, but further information is needed to assign a more precise stage.
Justification: The tumor is described as poorly differentiated in the pathology report.
Justification: This is an invasive malignant neoplasm, as evidenced by its growth into surrounding tissues and structures."

the trigone, are identified and probe patent.

Laterality: Some specimens specify laterality, such as the left and right ureters, pelvic and common iliac lymph nodes, and right para-aortic lymph nodes. Others do not provide information on laterality.

Histology: The histology of the specimens varies, including adenocarcinoma in the prostate and bladder, lymph nodes with and without masses, and a solid mass with red-tan parenchyma in the right para-aortic lymph nodes.
Stage: The stage is not provided for any of the specimens.
Grade: The grade is not provided for any of the specimens.
Behavior: The behavior of the specimens is described as malignant in the bladder and prostate, and further information on behavior is not provided for the other specimens.

Not all of the necessary information is provided for each specimen, such as stage, grade, and laterality in some cases. However, based on the available information, it can be determined that the specimens are from various sites, with different histologies and behaviors, but without information on staging or grading."

H:Sections of the bladder show multifocal urothelial carcinoma in situ (flat
lesion)[H1-4,6-101 and both non-invasive and invasive poorly differentiated
papillary urothelial carcinomas (H2-7,10 ),grade 4/4. Invasive carcinoma extends

with multiple foci of lymphovascular invasion (H5).Two incidental right
perivesical lymph nodes are identified both of which are free of malignancy (0/2).
Soft tissue resection margins are free of malignancy .Final resection margins of
both right and left ureters are free of both urothelial dysplasia and malignancy
(EFS, FPS ,J,K).Urothelial carcinoma in situ involves the initial apical
urethral margin (GFS), and along with non-invasive papillary carcinoma ,is also
noted to involve the urethra (I)where it focally extends to the meatus.

D:Sections of the exophytic mass lesion and adjacent ulcerated lesion seen
grossly on the mid to left dome region correspond histologically to invasive
transitional cell carcinoma (D2, D3, D4). The neoplastic cells have high NC ratio
with large pleomorphic hyperplastic nuclei and are arranged in solid sheets and
single cells. Extensive desmoplastic change is seen .The tumor extends through
the muscularis propria into the perivesical soft tissue to involve the peritoneum.
Multiple satellite tumor nodules are identified in the perivesical soft tissue. No
carcinoma in situ is identified .Extensive lymphovascular spaceinvasion i s seen.
Sections of the prostate show focal prostatic intraepithelial neoplasm (PIN II and
III) characterized by hyperplastic glands lined by stratified layers of enlarged
cells with corresponding large nuclei and variable prominent nucleoli.

Laterality: The lymph nodes and ureters are from both left and right sides of the pelvis.
Histology: The histological diagnosis is invasive transitional cell carcinoma based on the microscopic description.
Stage: Not provided, as it requires clinical correlation and assessment of tumor size, lymph node involvement, and metastasis.
Grade: Not explicitly mentioned in the pathology report, but focal prostatic intraepithelial neoplasm (PIN II and III) is noted in the sections of the prostate.
Behavior: Invasive transitional cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor with potential for aggressive behavior, including local invasion and metastasis."

Page 5 of 5 END OF REPORT"," Site: The specimen includes tissue from the urethra, bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, left and right ureters, and left pelvic lymph nodes.

Laterality: The tumor is located in the right posterior/lateral wall of the bladder, with involvement of the left orifice, urethra, and peri-urethral ducts. The left ureter and left pelvic lymph nodes were also examined.

Histology: The histological diagnosis is carcinoma in situ at the left orifice, with urethra and peri-urethral ducts involved. There is no stromal invasion, but there is vascular and perineural invasion. High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was also identified in the prostate.
Stage: The pathologic stage is pT3 (invasion of perivesical soft tissue) PRis (involvement of urethra or prostatic ducts without stromal invasion).
Grade: Not provided in the report.
Behavior: The behavior of this tumor is malignant, with potential for invasive growth and metastasis."

1 ! To / 1"," Based on the pathology report, here is the information for the six categories:
Site: The tumor is located in the breast. This is mentioned in the histological diagnosis as ""infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast.""
Laterality: The specific side of the body where the breast tumor is located is not provided in the report.

Histology: The tumor is an invasive ductal carcinoma, which means it started in a milk duct and has spread into the surrounding breast tissue. This is indicated in the histological diagnosis as ""infiltrating ductal carcinoma.""

Stage: The stage of the cancer is not explicitly stated in the report, but some information about the tumor size and lymph node involvement is provided. Based on this information, it appears that the tumor is at least stage II (T2 N1 M0), as it measures greater than 2 cm in diameter and has spread to at least one axillary lymph node.

Grade: The grade of the cancer is not explicitly stated in the report, but some information about the tumor's appearance is provided. Based on this information, it appears that the tumor is high-grade (grade 3), as it is described as having a ""high nuclear grade"" and being composed of ""poorly differentiated cells.""

Behavior: The behavior of the cancer is not explicitly stated in the report, but the fact that it is an invasive ductal carcinoma indicates that it is malignant and capable of spreading to other parts of the body. This is further supported by the finding of lymph node metastasis.

Justification: These categories were chosen because they are commonly used in cancer staging and provide important information about the tumor's location, size, spread, aggressiveness, and potential for metastasis."

Histology: The histology of the tumor is not explicitly provided in the report.
Justification: The report does not mention the type or subtype of bladder cancer present in the specimen.
Stage: Based on the gross and microscopic findings, the tumor appears to be at least muscle-invasive, which would put it at stage T2 or higher.
Justification: The report describes the mass invading through the muscularis propria into the perivesical fat, indicating that it has gone beyond the lamina propria and therefore is muscle-invasive.
Grade: The grade of the tumor is not provided in the report.
Justification: The report does not mention the degree of differentiation or aggressiveness of the tumor cells.
Behavior: The behavior of the tumor is considered malignant, based on the findings of invasion into surrounding tissues.

E:Sections of the bladder show an invasive poorly differentiated urothelial
carcinoma ,grades 3 & 4/4, that involves the left lateral wall (E5-9), trigone
(E10), left ureteral vesical junction (E12,13) and base of bladder (E14). The
tumor extends through the muscularis propria and into the perivesical fat but does
not involve the peritoneum or the inked margins .The closest inkedresection
margin is 0.2 cm from tumor (ES). Lymphovascular invasion is noted (E8,10,13).
Multiple foci of of mild to moderate urothelial dysplasia are identified in the
left lateral wall (E6, 8), trigone (E10), right UVJ (Ell), and left UVJ (E12, 13),
but no urothelial carcinoma in situ (flat lesion).

C:Sections of the bladder show a deeply invasive poorly differentiated papillary
urothelial carcinoma (C10-15) that extends through the entire wall into perivesical
fat (C10,12,13,15). A single focus of'vascular invasion is seen (C12). Resection
margins are free of malignancy. There is no associated in situ carcinoma (flat
lesion), either adjacent to the invasive tumor or in additional random sections of

Reviewer Initials"," Site: The primary tumor site is the urinary bladder, based on the microscopic examination of sections from the bladder (C10-15). Justification: Invasive poorly differentiated papillary urothelial carcinoma was identified in the bladder sections.

Laterality: The tumor is located in the left side of the urinary bladder, based on the presence of more extensive tumor involvement and deeper invasion in the left lateral wall (C6) compared to other walls. Justification: Although the tumor involves multiple sites, the most significant findings are seen in the left lateral wall.

Histology: The histological type of the primary tumor is urothelial carcinoma, based on microscopic examination (C10-15). Justification: Invasive poorly differentiated papillary urothelial carcinoma was identified in the bladder sections.

Stage: The tumor stage is muscle-invasive, based on the presence of tumor invasion through the entire wall into perivesical fat (C10, 12, 13, 15). Justification: Invasive urothelial carcinoma extending beyond the muscularis propria indicates a muscle-invasive stage.
Grade: The tumor grade is poorly differentiated, based on microscopic examination (C10-15). Justification: The tumor shows poor differentiation and lacks glandular or squamous differentiation.

Behavior: The behavior of the tumor is malignant, based on its invasive nature and histological features. Justification: Invasive urothelial carcinoma has a high potential for metastasis and recurrence, making it a malignant tumor.
Not provided: Prior malignancy history, dual/synchronous primary noted, HIPAA discrepancy, and reviewer initials are not provided in the given information."

D:Sections of the bladder show a poorly differentiated invasive urothelial
carcinoma (D1-3,9-11,13,14), grade 4/4, with focal clear features. The carcinoma
is associated with extensive ulceration and penetrates through the bladder wall
into perivesical soft tissue (D1,2,10,11). A focus of lymphovascular space
invasion is seen(D13). Carcinoma comes within 0.5 cm of the anterior radial margin
and 1.2 cm of the bladder neck margin. All other radial margins and bilateral
ureters margins are more widely free of malignancy. No trigone or ureterovesical
junction involvement by dysplasia or malignancy is seen .Metastatic urothelial
carcinoma is identified in one of three left perivesical lymph nodes examined
Sections of the uterus show a small focus of well differentiated endometrial
adenocarcinoma, FIGO grade 1/3, arising in association with endometrium and a polyp
containing complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia (D15-17). No myometrial or
cervical invasion is identified. All surgical margins are free of malignancy.
